subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS Frequency Chart posted to Files Section
msgSnippet: Thanks for the lead - it looks very interesting - I assume the RP stands for the infamous Received Pronunciation. ...
messageBody:
Thanks for the lead - it looks very interesting - I
assume the"RP" stands for the infamous "Received
Pronunciation."


--- Andii Bowsher <andii@...> wrote:

> There's a phoneme frequency chart at
>
http://victorian.fortunecity.com/vangogh/555/Spell/foneme-freq.html
> Which is really helpful in establishing frequency of
> occuranc of the
> different phonemes. I think it should be too hard
> to map to QS.
> -Andii
>
> mcbroom1946 wrote:
>
> >There has been much tossed around lately about the
> frequency of QS
> >letters (and how this affects new keyboard
> layouts.) Here is my humble
> >contribution to the question,
> >
> >For a convenient source, I used two of the largest
> texts in the files
> >section of the Shavian Group: a Sherlock Holmes
> story (70KB) and a chapter
> >of "The Uses of English" (58KB) The total character
> count was about 67,000,
> >20% of which were spaces. Of course, all
> transcriptions are affected by
> >the ear of the translator (and I think in both
> cases it was possibly
> >our reknown member Hugh) but we have to start
> somewhere, and I think the
> >results would much the same with different sources,
> at least for the first dozen
> >letters.
> >
> >Here are the adjustments made to the originals:
> >1) Shavian "array" and "urge" were combined into QS
> "earth"
> >2) Shavian "ado" and "up" were combined into QS
> "ado" (one form only).
> >3) All ligatures were broken down into their
> components and assigned
> >to their root sounds.
> >4) Because of the source, of course, no ligatures
> or letter variants
> >were counted. (I think this to be an asset, We
> should be counting SOUNDS
> >not SHAPES!)
> >
> >Because Yahoo, in their infinite wisdom, will not
> let me attach the
> >chart, I have posted it to the Read files
> section/resources. Enjoy! Feedback
> >appreciated.
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>

Thanks for the lead - it looks very interesting - I
assume the"RP" stands for the infamous "Received
Pronunciation."
